title: How to Stop Smoking When You Have Schizophrenia

content: It’s unfortunate, but many of us who live with schizophrenia also smoke. (About 62% of us, research shows. That’s a higher percentage of smokers than found in the general population.)

Smoking helps us manage and cope with stress. But it causes a variety of health conditions – coronary heart disease, asthma, and cancers, to name a few. Combine that with the statistic that, in the U.S., people with schizophrenia die about 28 years earlier than people without a serious mental health condition. It'd help if we quit smoking altogether.
In an effort to understand why so many of us smoke, I did some research and found that nicotine can increase and regulate dopamine and glutamate levels when you have schizophrenia.

Nicotine is known to alter the release of virtually all major neurotransmitters and stimulates the release of dopamine in broad target areas throughout your brain. It suggests that smoking helps correct dopamine deficiency in your prefrontal cortex and relieves some of schizophrenia’s negative symptoms. It’s unclear how nicotine is linked to positive symptoms. More research is needed.

content: Quitting smoking isn’t an easy task. I know from personal experience. I’ve smoked for the last 30 years. I’ve tried to quit cold turkey many times – without success. So a few months ago, I put serious thought into quitting smoking.

I’ve got reasons for wanting to quit. I’m not getting any younger, and I want to live a healthier life. Smoking is an expensive habit, and I hope to save money. I don’t enjoy smoking anymore. I don’t like the smell of cigarettes in my hair and on my clothes.

I realize this won’t be easy. I know it’ll take time and a lot of work. What’s promising, though, is the abundance of smoking cessation aids and programs to choose from. There are many different ways to quit smoking.
The first thing I did was talk with my primary care doctor. I worked with them to create my plan to quit smoking. Since I have insurance through my job, I was able to get nicotine patches.

The first thing I did was talk with my primary care doctor. I worked with them to create my plan to quit smoking. Since I have insurance through my job, I was able to get nicotine patches.

content: It’s best to quit smoking cigarettes completely before starting the patch. If you smoke while on the patch, you could develop atrial fibrillation (AFib), which is an irregular heart rhythm that begins in your heart’s upper chambers (atria).

I also called the CDC’s 1-800-QUIT-NOW line to see if they could offer more assistance. I found this to be an excellent resource. Since I have insurance, they weren’t able to give me smoking cessation aids. But, if you don’t have insurance, or if your insurance doesn’t cover this, they’ll provide you with free nicotine patches, gum, or lozenges.

While I’m still getting the nicotine patches prescribed to me from my doctor, I’m getting free support counseling from 1-800-QUIT-NOW. I’m really happy this service is offered. It’ll keep me accountable for my progress.
Once a week, I do a check-in of my progress with my support liaison, to let them know how I’m doing and to get support. They give me tips that help me quit for good.

content: This is a habit I have to change. I have to change not only when I smoke, but why. I usually smoke first thing in the morning, after every meal, when I’m stressed, and while driving my car.

To break some of my habits, I slowly decreased how many cigarettes I smoke, and I delayed when I smoke. For instance, instead of smoking 10 minutes after waking up, I wait until my morning routine is done. I also don’t let myself smoke when I’m driving. After I eat, I find something pleasant to do, like journaling or sketching.

I’ve loaded up on sugar-free gum and hard candy to help get over the oral fixation I have with cigarettes. I find this very helpful. So, after every meal, I chew gum or have candy. It’s a treat to taste something sweet.

I’m happy to say I’m on the patch and doing well with my smoking cessation journey. If you’re living with schizophrenia and want to quit smoking, take the time to find out when and why you smoke. Reach out for help.
